intro: Gilia wrightii, commonly known as Wright's gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, clustered flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer. Wright's gilia is often found in open woodlands and along streambanks, contributing to the ecological diversity of its habitat.
